Award.AwardTitle: Thirtieth Cumberland Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory and Computing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 30th Cumberland Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory and Computing will be held at Marshall University, May 19-20, 2018. This is the latest in a series of conferences, usually held annually, that provide a venue for students and researchers, particularly but not exclusively from the southeastern United States, to discuss the latest advances in discrete mathematics and computer science. Discrete mathematics is a rapidly expanding field with applications in communication, network and information science, life sciences and engineering. The conference will promote applications of discrete mathematics in computer science and encourage participation by students and groups underrepresented in mathematics. It provides a setting where researchers at all levels can present their work, exchange information and collaborate on solving problems. It strengthens the regional network of researchers while connecting that network to broader national and international communities.

The conference scope includes all areas of discrete mathematics. Four featured internationally-known speakers will give 50-minute plenary presentations. Estimated attendance is around 100 participants, and about 60 contributed 20-minute talks are planned. Abstracts from the conference will be available indefinitely through a conference abstracts service. Funding from this award will support travel, accommodation and meal expenses for the featured speakers, and other participants identified through a selection process. The selection process will prioritize women, members of underrepresented minorities, people with disabilities, early-career mathematicians, and researchers without federal funding. The conference website is http://www.marshall.edu/math/cumberland2018/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 30th Cumberland Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory and Computing took place at Marshall University in Huntington, West Virginia on Saturday, May 19 and Sunday, May 20, 2018. The conference location was Smith Hall at Marshall University. The organizers were JiYoon Jung and Michael Schroeder (principal investigator) of Marshall University.

The conference covered a broad range of topics in the general area of combinatorics, graph theory and computing. The 57 participants mostly came from the southeastern United States. The conference featured four plenary talks given by the following distinguished speakers:

* Charlie Colbourn, Arizona State University
* Patricia Hersh, North Carolina State University
* Greg Warrington, University of Vermont
* Michael Young, Iowa State University

There were also 33 twenty-minute talks (with five additional minutes for questions) by other speakers. (35 talks were scheduled, but two speakers were unable to attend.) These talks ran in two parallel sessions throughout the conference. The conference seems to have been a definite success and to have achieved its goal of allowing participants to see some of the important new developments in the area.

All of the National Science Foundation (NSF) funding was used to provide travel support to participants who requested support via an application process. Twenty-three people were supported in this way, including two undergraduate students, 6 graduate students and 2 early-career mathematicians. NSF funding also paid for some of the expenses of the plenary speakers.

The conference web site may be found at

https://www.marshall.edu/math/cumberland2018/

The "Schedule of Talks" link under the "Program" heading provides an outline of the program, with abstracts available.
